Different sets of 3d objects to enhance the usability and functions for the Ferplast star aquarium series. Most designs can be applied to the aluminum profiles and enclosure of the ferplast star 120, 160, 200.  
These designs are made from a private person and are not from the official manufactures. All names/trademarks belong to their owners.

• Cable holder = holds silicone tubes or cables in position (from co2, air, etc)
  • jbl outlet hanger = fixes the jbl outlet pipes to the middle of the aquarium so they don't bend.
  • toolbox = can be hanged to the aquarium, for permanently usage please use the optional enclosure cover spacer
  • toolbox enclosure 1 = tools left + holes for water tests (see pic)
  • aqualantis easy led adapter = strong and slim t5 holder to perfectly fit an aqualnatis easy led aquarium led light instead the basic reflector on the top enclosure, led light will hang higher than the normal reflector t5's [!new!]

• new files will be uploaded with time
  • all files were designed to be printed with pla

• needs to be printed with supports
  • can be hanged to the aquarium (please close the aquarium carefully)

This is just a first rough draft. I'll be updating this later to add the holes and I may possibly hollow it out as well. As it stands, these pieces are super strong and consume quite a bit of filament. I would suggest printing with 10 to 15 % infill instead of the default 25.

If you happen to have one of these excellent thermoses and would like a handle for it, then I've got just the thing for you!  
I designed this in three parts for easy printing with no support. The parts are wedged-shaped so they automatically tighten the ring around the thermos when you slide them together - no hardware or glue needed!   
Oh, and the supplied handle file does not have "BRIAN" on it, since that would be weird if your name wasn't Brian.  
SketchUp 8 files included for those who want to tweak this for their own purposes.

Print with no support. The parts are pretty beefy, so you can skimp on the infill. You will need two rings and one handle.  
The ideal ring size will slide easily onto the thermos from the top, but will not slide off the bottom. Slight scaling might be necessary to suit your printer.  
After printing, remove the thermos lid, slide on one ring (wider wedge opening up), slide the handle into place while pressing the two parts together with your fingers, then slide on the last ring (wider wedge opening down) and press together just like the bottom. Fill with a tasty beverage and replace the lid.

title: Ice Fishing Pole with Automatic Jigging Action!!!

description.text: The company I work for is having an Ice Fishing competition and I didnt have a ice fishing pole. Why buy one when you can design and print one?!? So the "Ice Kajigger" was born. With a few attachments like the Beer Bottle Opener and the Arduino powered "Kajigg-o-Matic", it turned out to be an awesome pole. Just sit back, crack open a cold one and let the pole do the work. :) Thanks, and enjoy! :) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qsyowDFicYk&feature=youtu.be

I used M8 x 60 bolts to attach the reel, tip, and handle to the mid section. The reel is printed in two pieces. Glue them together and throw few 608 bearings and some washers and two nuts and you have yourself a functional reel. The reel handle uses m3 x 40 bolt and some smaller bearings (i can't remember the bearing size) and a nylock nut to hold it all in place. For the tip of the rod you need to find an old fishing pole and chop off the tip, about 18" and glue it into the printed tip section. I tried to print a rod tip but it wasnt strong enough to be practical. The Kajigg-o-Matic uses an Arduino Uno programmed with a basic Servo Sweep program. The servo is a small 9g micro. All powered by two 18650 batteries. The battery holder is also a non printed part. I picked it up at digikey.  
I'll try to make an assembly tutorial if people actually want to print this and make their own Ice Kajigger.

description.text: Vases for plants

This case is designed to be laser cut from 3mm and 5mm acrylic. It
forms a four bay enclosure for Lenovo serial Ultrabay enhanced drives (12.7mm). The serial Ultrabay slim and Ultrabay Slim do fit but have gaps above them. The tolerances are very close but the design has been successfully
realised, though even the protective plastic covering upsets the slot
sizes enough to cause issues. Using 1/8th inch acrylic does not work with this design! Layer 0 (black) is the through sheet profile cut. Layer 1 (red) is the connector and slot cutouts Layer 2 (yellow) is the text There are three dxf files the first two are to be cut from 3mm
material and are only split for my convenience in fabrication. Sheet
three is to be cut from 5mm material and forms support slides. Assembly is somewhat fiddly but everything does go together. The
easiest approach seems to be to start with the right side wall flat on
a desk and assemble parts onto the slots, then add the left side and
back and front.

I was impressed by benjaminbellamy's spool holder but I wanted to make some modifications. In fact I wrote totally new scad files with almost all options configurable (you can change all sizes, bearings, count of arms and so on). My holder is bigger and has interchangeable centering ring so a lot of spools can fit it. But the idea of design was not changed.
This spool holder can be used with a lot of spool's types, it only need to change centering ring. You can print it "as is" or change almost everything in configuration file. You should generate or print centering rings for each of your spools.
My holder is printed with PLA and the base is 20cm (almost 8") diameter.

You can print it using .STL files or you can change configuration in spool_holder_config.scad file and regenerate all stls from .SCAD files, then print it! If you want you can adjust almost all in this holder - from size, bearing type, shape and count of arms!
You should print another centering ring for each spools you use. The centering ring should fit into your spool's central hole.
You should never print spool_holder_assembly.scad file - it's only for preview!

comments.text: Yes, you should. This surface is there instead of support - otherwise printer would have to print over the air. You should drill it as deep as needed to put it together. This is a thin surface, so you can alternatively use a knife.

remixed_from.author: benblur4
remixed_from.title: Printrbot Simple Adjustable Spool Stand / Coaster

description.text: I had an idea for a spool holder that sits on top of my Printrbot Metal Plus. The printer design is such that you can just set a spool up there, and it pretty much works, but I was worried it might fall over or something. I took the 80mm gap at the top, and used pieces from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:178862 to create a spool holder that rests on top of my printer and fits into the gap, but uses the bearings instead of just resting on the bare metal. I used a couple 1/4 20 lag bolts to act as spacers, and hold it together. Not bad for a first draft of an idea. This thing was made with Tinkercad.

Print the two halves.  I recommend black to go with your awesome looking printer.  
Press fit the roller bearings onto the posts.  This model uses 608ZZ Roller bearings I got for another project.  It helps to use a vise to gently press the bearing onto the post.  
Get a couple 1/4" bolts long enough to fit your spool when inserted through the holes. Slide them through the outer two holds, and loosely tighten the bolts on.  You want it just wider than your spool width.  If you have different sized spools, you can loosen your bolts, or use longer bolts.  
Set the assembly  on top of your printer.  
Drop spool on, and feed the filament into your extruder.  Make sure the spool spins freely.  
Print. and feel awesome.

comments.text: This is a great holder design, very close to what I was planning to create on my own! It printed out and fit the bearings perfectly, and now I can fit my Hatchbox spool, which was just too small to fit on the Metal's power supply handle. Great work!

A very basic design made to solve a problem quick and test a theory, will it generally work.
It is designed to fit a table 25mm thick and have 10mm MIN access to push the clip fully on.
It is intended to hold 1-2 standard power cables or several smaller USB or other cables and stop them slipping off the back of the desk. Thereby saving you from going all the way under to push them back up.
Also they can be turned upside down withe the loops hanging below the desk to provide a method of hanging some cable up and away from the floor or your feet. A colleague recently crashed his partners pc (sitting opposite) due to cable hanging down.
Hope everyone, anyone finds it useful and of course I will be updating it and uploading other variations.
The Cable Desk Clip was modelled in GeoMagic Design Elements 'Alibre' and printed on a Leapfrog Creatr HS to check that the design functionally work, it does quite well.

title: 2.5 inch to 3.5 hard drive adapter for hotswap drives

description.text:
There are a number of 2.5" to 3.5" hard drive brackets on thingiverse, but ALL the other ones don't seem to be for hotswap server bays with drive caddies (because they don't mount the SSD in the required position).
That may be because you can just screw your SSD into the corner of the caddy with two screws, but if you want it to be a tiny bit more secure, just print this out and screw it to the SSD drive (and then to the caddy).
Print and use!

author: zhoujianfu

title: Prusa I3 wood frame filament guide

description.text:
After fighting with several other filament guides I decided to make one for the wood frame version of the Prusa I3. The problem with all the other guides I have seen is that they all cause the filament to slide over a hard point and that causes noise and wear. So enter the pulley guide.   
I printed mine at 0.2 layer height and 190 Celsius, with PLA.  
After two weeks with it at 100% scale, I reprinted at 200%. It is much smoother, and holds the filament better at the larger size. Just a tip!

When you go to assemble this:  
I used a piece of 3mm filament as the pin and then melted the ends to hold it all together. Then just screw it to the very top edge of the wooden frame and place your spool of filament behind the printer.

remixed_from.author: walter
remixed_from.title: Sleeve Case for Raspberry Pi B+

title: Raspberry Pi B+ bracket for Printrbot Simple Metal

description.text:
I made one of these great sleeve cases for my Raspberry Pi B+.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:604915 I wanted to be able to mount it on my Printrbot Simple Metal, so I started by making a device to attach it easily to the PSM. Using sketchup and a bit of trial and error I came up with a bracket that would clip onto the bottom of the two 12mm Z-axis rods. The second piece is just a simple saddle clamp for the Pi case. It hangs off the bracket. you may want to print two of the PiClip.stl and you can position them however you like on the Pi case, depending on what ports you require access to.
Please note the bracket is 5 mm thick. Be sure you have sufficient clearance on your PSM when the Z-axis is homed. Mine has approx 7-8mm of clearance there and this bracket works fine.

comments.text: Printed this out today and sad to say, I didn't have much luck.  The thin upright piece snapped while trying to clean out the support material.  I was thinking of an alternative method for this.  If removed the clip from the bracket, it could be printed on it's side without support.  Add a tab on one end that would lay on top of the bracket and it could then be glued into position.  I was trying to do something like that by importing the STL into OpenSCAD but unfortunately, there is something about the STL that causes CGAL to crash when rendering it after it has been clipped.  I have had this problem with other STL files.
comments.author: ElmoC

comments.text: I'm sorry it didn't print well for you. I am in the process of redoing this one a bit. I have made a new clip that has a 5mm high x 3mm wide rail along the edge. I will draw out a new bracket to go with it. Maybe with a more flexible design, the rail can be used to hang different things from the side. I am uploading the new clip now.
comments.author: ElmoC

comments.text: I knew it was going to be problematic for me.  I have not had much luck with tall structures printed this way so you only have the layer adhesion for strength.  I'll give your new one a try.  I have another RPi case that uses screws that I was going to try making a bracket for to attach with the clip.  On the plus side, the clip fits perfectly.  :)
comments.author: savant9

comments.text: Well I'm glad the clip part works! I have just updated everything to the 2 piece design now. I have also uploaded the Pi saddle clamp. It fits mine well with only a single clip. I like this set up much better.

title: Electric Drive Add-on for Gatling Rubber Band Gun

description.text: This uses a stepper motor to add an electric drive for the Gatling Rubber Band Gun (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:647475). The crank arm from the original Gatling Rubber Band Gun should be removed, and this add-on secured to the Rear Body using zip ties. Requires a bit of electronics and soldering. Details are in the instructions. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FMEkEvbr3Qs

3D parts designed in FreeCAD (fcstd file is included) and printed in PLA using Cura. Electronic parts laid out using DIY Layout Creator. Print using the individual component's STL file, and refer to the image to see how everything fits together. For higher speed (...and less torque), use v2 of the gears. Besides the 3D prints, you'll also need...
  • Stepper motor (I'm using the ASTROSYN Y129, http://sg.element14.com/astrosyn/y129/stepper-motor-1-8deg-12v/dp/9598642, but you can use any other NEMA stepper of the same size)
  • Atmel ATtiny13 Microcontroller (1 pc) (you can also use the ATtiny 85, but will need to make some minor changes during compilation and upload).
  • 7805 Voltage Regulator (1 pc) (...or any 5V regulators will do)
  • BS170 MOSFET (4 pc) (you can use the 2N7000, but if you do, you'll need to mount it in reverse)
  • Terminal blocks (6-ways) (Something like this http://sg.element14.com/camdenboss/ctb3051-2bk/terminal-block-wire-to-brd-2pos/dp/3882615?ost=3882615)
  • On/Off switch (1 pc) (This sholud be fine http://sg.element14.com/multicomp/1ms4t1b1m1re/switch-spdt/dp/9473467)
  • Stripboard / PCB board
  • Battery Holder (8 batteries)
  • Wires
  • Zip tie / Cable tie
    • Compiling...
  • You can used the provided hex file for direct upload to your ATtiny, or you can compile using.
  • avr-gcc -g -Wall -O2 -mmcu=attiny13 -c -o stepper.o stepper.c
  • avr-gcc -g -Wall -O2 -mmcu=attiny13 -Wl,-Map,stepper.map -o stepper.elf stepper.o -lm
  • avr-objcopy -j .text -j .data -O ihex stepper.elf stepper.hex

comments.text:
HA! NICE! :)
You beat me to it! I was just going to use a standard 'pinky' motor that is real common throughout Thingiverse, and direct drive.
I'm guessing that with the stepper and controller, you'd have a lot more flexibility for speed and also you'd have a lot of torque.

Update - In the _v2 large corner pieces that I just uploaded, I removed the overhang that was causing the captured pieces to stick together in some prints. I have test printed another cube and the new _v2 pieces work great. I did have to tap the bottom of two of the large corners lightly with a pair of pliers to pop the middle loose. It took much less effort than before and I think they would have stayed separate if I had turned the temp down a little more during the print. The gold pictures are of the new one. I also realized that the one corner makes a nice little stand! I was getting ready to print another copy of my Amazing Gyroscopic Cube Gears and got to thinking that while it is very cool that it is able to incorporate all of the motions it has, it is actually pretty plain. I incorporated a ton of hearts in many different ways when I created the Fantastical Gyroscopic Heart gears, but I wanted to something more artistic. 3D printing is after all a great platform for art work. So, I started thinking about what kind of styling really fit with it and immediately thought that a steampunk style would be perfect! Given that the cube gears is the center piece of the Amazing Gyroscopic Cube Gears (I really need to think of shorter names) I decided to start there and got to work. All eight of the corners and even the center piece have been steampunked. For the large gears, I wanted to add another level, so I modified them to print as two captured parts where the middle is tied to the cube center while the outside moves. This allowed me to add some interesting aspects. I felt that it wouldn't have the full effect without being painted to fit the style, so I went to the store and got an assortment of metallic acrylic paints and a fine point paint brush. I think that it turned out great! Here's a video of it:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aYsdtDzSaB4&feature=youtu.be Update - I added a couple of pictures of the progress I have made on the Steampunk gyroscopic cube gears I designed this cube for. The small and large rings and gears are complete and turning well. They are unpainted in the picture though. I am working on the uprights now.

Per a request, I added some reference pictures for the assembly with notes.  The description below provides better detail though.  
The v2 large corners function the same and are easier to print than the originals, so I removed the original large corners from the files.  
Print all of the parts.    It is designed to print Without support.  If you use support, separate parts will get fused together. There are some overhangs and some minor bridges.  Nothing too bad.  I recommend setting your printer to print outlines from inside to outside since that helps with overhangs.  
I printed it in  PLA .2 mm layers at 100mm/sec with a fan blowing on the print around my nozzle.  
There are many small details in these prints that can be delicate.  make sure that you are careful to handle them by the bigger parts.  Also keep in mind that if you drop it, it will break.  
The large corners are two parts with one captured within the other.  The tolerances are tight, so you may need to break them loose if they stick to each other.  After trying different things, I found that it works best to hold the large corner in one hand and tap the center lightly until it breaks loose.  I used a pair of pliers for this.  
I recommend lubricating it before assembling.  If you have read any of my instructions for other moving prints, you will notice a trend.  I always recommend CRC Heavy Duty Silicone spray.  There is a reason for this.  It really works very well.  Buy one can and it will last forever because you need very little.  
Spray CRC Heavy Duty Silicone spray on all moving contacts and let it dry for a few hours before assembly. After assembling a part and making sure that it moves well, I will usually spray it some more by sticking the spray straw into cracks and then turn the pieces to work it in. Then I let it dry overnight. When it is wet, it can actually stick and even stop turning, so don't force it. Let it dry and be AMAZED when it moves so freely after it dries.  
When assembling,  Take care to line up the pieces correctly.  Some of these pieces are fragile and consequently hard to get connected.  The last thing that you want is to have to remove a piece because it was not lined up.  
I find that it helps to give the pins a gentle squeeze with a pair of pliers first to help break them in.  
I inserted the pins in the large pieces first and connected them to the center piece.  Large pieces 1 and 4 are not that bad to get connected.  Piece 2 is not bad either.  Just be careful not to break off the chimney pipe.  Piece 3 was tricky.  I pushed in the pin as far as I felt safe doing it.  Then I found that it worked best if I stuck a skinny screwdriver through the bars to hold against the bottom.  This allowed me to provide enough force to push the pin into the cube center.  
After you add the large corners, put on the small corners, being careful to line each one up properly.  Make sure that everything is lubed and you are done!  
Next show it to everyone and amaze them with what you can create with your 3D printer!!!  
I am now working on the parts for a steampunk version of the Amazing Gyroscopic Cube Gears.  Stay tuned!

remixed_from.title: Customizable drawer box with hex pattern sides

title: Slightly Modified Drawer Box With Hex Pattern Sides

description.text:
I modified the version 6 OpenSCAD file to use writecube command instead of simply write so that the text would be centered on the drawer face. Added the ability to select from available fonts used by write library for the text on the drawers. Also moved the position of the dimple stops so as to not interfere with the drawer dividers as it does in the original design. With the dimples being in the middle of the drawer the only drawer that would work in the original design would be the single slot drawer. By offsetting the dimples into the middle of the slotted areas it increases the stops holding the drawer in as well as prevent the divider interference. Warning:
  • Something has caused customizer to not take the spacing value being passed to the writecube command. Not sure if this is specific to another recent change or not. Compiling locally in OpenSCAD is working correctly.
    • Updates:
  • 02/16/2015: Uploaded additional example stl files showing raised text to complement the already uploaded embossed versions. These are in essence the same as the predecessor thing with the addition of updated dimple stops. Removed top dimple stops to hopefully help make the drawers not get stuck. Doing this might lead me to revert to original design and put a single dimple in the middle of the drawer.
  • 02/19/2015: Modified bottom of drawer to have tracks between the bump stops front to back (not yet tested).

I designed this extruder cooler for my Replicator 1 based on one main need:  I use a removable glass build plate affixed with springy metal clips.  These clips stick up off the build platform and will hit anything slightly lower than the gantry.  Because of this, I designed this to shoot a jet of air just below the tip of the nozzle, but keeping the whole apparatus above the base of the gantry.   
It's designed to not need any additional hardware (other than a 24v 40mm fan) to install.

Print Directions:
  • Sliced in Simplify 3d with these settings:
  • 200 micron, 2 shells, 20% infill, gray PLA printed @ 200 deg.
  • Designed to not need any supports.
    • Install Instructions:
  • You'll need a 40mm x 10mm fan, 24v + connectors / long wires.
  • Remove the left M3 bolt from the stepstruder fan: Remove the black plastic standoff between the fan and the radiator.
  • Insert the cooler where the standoff used to be: Re-insert the M3 bolt and tighten as normal.
  • I connected my fan with a few small zip-ties, then did a border of hot-glue just to seal it up. But if you have your own M3 bolts, holes are provided.
  • Run the +- leads from the fan around the existing wiring harness (or in the harness) to the "Extra" terminal on the Mightyboard (near a corner).
  • Be sure to enable cooling in your slicer!
    • Fan options:
  • Makerbot
  • Jameco

title: OpenSCAD MakerBot Font Module
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: After seeing the great work of tbuser and avrgeek I was inspired to create an OpenSCAD module for the font used by MakerBot Industries. The font itself is called Designer Block by K-Type (http://www.k-type.com/?p=296). It's free for personal use but K-Type require a paid license for commercial use. I've licensed this Thing under a non-commercial license to highlight this. If you own a license for the font then feel free to contact me for a relicensed version of this Thing that you can derive for commercial use. I had hoped to extend avrgeek's code to provide proper support for variable-width fonts. Unfortunately the limitations in the OpenSCAD language hampered my efforts but the examples provided show how you can manually kern the text to get around this problem. You'll see from the Character Test that some of the characters (G, H, T and ?) currently fail to render. This is apparently due to a winding direction problem I've yet to fix. For the MBI logo I've worked around it by carefully hacking a replacement T out of an I and a hypen. :) If there is interest in better font support for OpenSCAD I might look into some of the scripting language interfaces that may be useful for generating OpenSCAD code that will properly kern the selected font. As it stands you might be better off just typing up the text in Inkscape and importing it into OpenSCAD as a DXF for linear extrusion. I've included avrgeek's Customize.txt which contains basic instructions for porting new fonts. I have yet to print anything using this font so I have no idea whether it will even work. :)

title: Printrbase 2 ATX Power Supply Case for PrintrBot Simple Metal with Heated Bed

description.text:
This is a base for an ATX power supply for a printrbot simple metal with heated bed. It cleans up the wiring by keeping the ATX wires internal to a case.  
My first version of this (Thing #512601) used a smaller power supply and was build-able in two pieces. This version is a bit larger and should be able to fit most any ATX power supply, however it has to be printed in 4 pieces. Like my first version, the printrbot intentionally hangs over the front edge in order to give access to the reset button.

Print the front left, front right, back left and back right pieces.
The front left and front right pieces snap together. The back left and back right pieces snap together. (Actually, it works better if you slide them together rather than snap them together)
The front and back assemblies are then held together with screws. Solidworks files included for those that want to modify it.

comments.text:
I printed mine in PLA with no issues. Used about a half a kilogram, around 180meters. (1.75mm PLA is around 330meters per kilogram)
I use a sharpened 1-inch putty knife to remove the piece from the bed. Gently tap it between the bed and the piece and it usually comes up with no problem.
I ended up heat welding the left and right halves together after assembling them for a little added strength. I also had to slightly enlarge the screw holes for the power supply since they didn't quite line up with my power supply. One thing missing on this design is a good way to attach the base to the printer to make it stay together when moving it around. I'm using tie wraps - they work, but it is not an elegant solution.

title: Kossel Effector for E3D V6 hotend

description.text:
I made this thing! An effector plate for my kossel, the one supplied needed severe mods to take the E3D so i dowloaded Ponpont's excellent plate from here. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:439497 But I found i didn't need a probe!
(what can I say, i paid attention while building!, the bed is glass, and therefore flat, and i spent some time making the frame and rods right, so calibration does not budge. ever, at all, not even a tiny bit, well only when I change nozzle)
But I did manage to knacker a thermistor AND heater in striping down and rebuilding a few times when the hotend clogged, so i thought rather than a probe some connection points for the thermistor and fan might be more useful, so I added a square hole to take a 4-way dupont connector with a screw to lock it in place, i push the 4way through the top of the plate until a couple of mm are sticking out below the plate, then make short leads onto the thermistor and the fan, and plug these in from the underside. Makes life very easy when stripping down!
I have a couple of heavy duty spade connectors on the heater leads, pop these open,
unplug and remove the fan,
unplug the thermistor,
then i can just screw the heaterblock straight out of the hotend - Simples! Also I kinda hate the captive nut approach as there is not enough room to get at the damn things, so i adopted slots. they are a bit oversize, sometimes i need to wedge a small screwdriver down between a flat on the nut and the side of the hole to tighten up. a bit crap, but much easier than supporting the effector and rod end, threading in a bolt and trying to keep the captive nut in position.... It's probably a bit heavy, but it hasn't caused me any problems so far...(famous last words)

comments.text: The nut holes are too over sized, the nuts just spin in place, especially at the hotend holes. Its better to have those holes undersized than oversized because you can press fit a nut into there. Are these not sized for M3 nuts? Try making them the same size as the nuts +0.2 mm.

title: Tiny part for G-code file testing

description.text:
I wanted a way to look at the G-code start and end codes that are created by slicing packages.  Slic3r won't let me write a G-code without having an STL file loaded.  My solution was to design a cube with 1mm edge dimensions.  This produces a G-code file of only a few kb and a few hundred lines.  If you want the smallest file, make sure you turn off loops, skirt and brim so that the body of the G code only "prints" the cube.  
I haven't tried printing this.  I doubt it would be very exciting, but you are welcome to try.

title: Sleeve Case for Raspberry Pi B+ / Pi 2

description.text: This is an adaption of the case walter put together at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:604915. I found a couple things that were issues with the cases I printed, so I modified it and am hopeful someone else may find use for the changes as well. It is worthwhile noting it is the Pi 2 that I am working with, not the Pi rev B. That could be part of the issue with the tolerances but as I understood, the board layout was to be identical. I changed the slot size at the bottom of the case. The original slot had too tight of tolerance so the spring action in the slot could not engage or disengage when inserting the card. I also found because of the tolerances it was impossible for me to get the card out of the Pi once it was inserted. There was a slot inside the case for the connectors up to the point of the audio port. That worked until the HDMI port would get caught. By the time the board is in that far, there is not a lot of wiggle room to get the connector past that point without putting a lot of strain on the connectors. So I extended the internal slot to the HDMI location, and now it slides in without catching there. The audio port still catches, but it is manageable. As a last minute change, I also increased the size of the audio port hole. The other port holes have plenty of space around them, but the audio port was pretty tight. Once in position it would line up fine, but I increased the size of the hole around the port a little bit. Edit: Reviewing some posts on the source of the case, some have had luck scaling the case by 1mm. May have been easier than changing the case to begin with, but it was still a fun project regardless. :)
Printed using 2 shells, 85% fill, no rafts or supports.

comments.text: Works fine with pla, 0,1mm thickness and 40 percent infill. RPI3 fits well
comments.author: vitaly12

comments.text: I printed this, but it didn't turn out well. One problem is a fundamental design issue, I think. Sliding the Pi in, there just isn't good clearance for the audio port. It's really a tight fit and even when I went ahead and forced it, I couldn't get it in far enough. Not willing to try any more and risk breaking the Pi. Second issue was that the vent slits are too narrow and most of mine ended up with stringing across them. Yes, probably somewhat do to some more fine tuning that I need to do. But also due to the need for the extruder to jump a bunch of small gaps when printing. I've found another design that I think is going to work much better...one of the two-piece screw together cases that can be printed flat, eliminating the issue with unintentionally bridging the vent slits when printing, and also avoiding the need to jam the Pi into too small of a hole.

author: pcarlson

description.text:
Large mouth canning jar lid for lacto-fermentation (vapor lock). I really liked thecharacterg's version although I didn't want to take up jar space so I mimicked his design a bit. Update (2/20):
Alright fellow hobbyists! Well I now have most of the kinks worked out and it is up and running (or sitting). All corrections have been made although I did not get a fill level on it. A rubber band works fine as a seal as well.

Printed with PLA at 18% infill (although 15% would probably be fine).  
There is a lip support in the drawing which will easily break free so no tools should be necessary for removal.  I use a rubber band to seal the jar which seems to work just fine.  You'll also need to use a canning band to tighten down (I didn't know how to make threads).  
Just fill it up about halfway with water to complete your airlock and let your recipe sit.  Be aware, I'm unsure how to clean it so I just figure to make sure to dry it well after I am finished.  Also, maybe try to lightly cover the top to keep dust out of the airlock for long term cleanliness.  
Anyway, I hope it works well for you all and have a great spring, summer, autumn, & winter!

comments.text: Thanks for sharing this! You've been using it for a while now, so how's it working for you?

comments.text: Honestly I only used it once.  Seemed to work out nicely although I since got a travel job and basically stopped preparing food and cooking altogether, unfortunately.

Hāfez was a Persian poet who "laud[ed] the joys of love and wine [but] also targeted religious hypocrisy". His collected works are regarded as a pinnacle of Persian literature and are to be found in the homes of most people in Iran, who learn his poems by heart and use them as proverbs and sayings to this day. His life and poems have been the subject of much analysis, commentary and interpretation, influencing post-fourteenth century Persian writing more than any other author. Hafez is the most popular poet in Iran, and his works can be found in almost every Iranian home. In fact, October 12 is celebrated as Hafez Day in Iran. Tomb of Hafez in Shiraz
Twenty years after his death, a tomb, the Hafezieh, was erected to honor Hafez in the Musalla Gardens in Shiraz. The current mausoleum was designed by André Godard, a French archeologist and architect, in the late 1930s, and the tomb is raised up on a dais amidst rose gardens, water channels, and orange trees. Inside, Hafez's alabaster sarcophagus bears the inscription of two of his poems. His tomb is "crowded with devotees" who visit the site and the atmosphere is "festive", with visitors singing and reciting their favorite Hafez poems. O beautiful wine-bearer, bring forth the cup and put it to my lips
Path of love seemed easy at first, what came was many hardships. With its perfume, the morning breeze unlocks those beautiful locks
The curl of those dark ringlets, many hearts to shreds strips. In the house of my Beloved, how can I enjoy the feast
Since the church bells call the call that for pilgrimage equips. With wine color your robe, one of the old Magi’s best tips
Trust in this traveler’s tips, who knows of many paths and trips. The dark midnight, fearful waves, and the tempestuous whirlpool
How can he know of our state, while ports house his unladen ships. I followed my own path of love, and now I am in bad repute
How can a secret remain veiled, if from every tongue it drips? If His presence you seek, Hafiz, then why yourself eclipse?
Stick to the One you know, let go of imaginary trips. (Hafez)

A Unicorn-compatible mount for the same laser pointer as in the LAZOR mount thing. The LAZOR mount is technically an ancestor of this design, as I used that base as a starting point when designing this. Includes a mount for a micro servo and a flag to block the laser beam. This should be compatible with the unicorn firmware & hookup. I haven't assembled yet, but I think the pen down angle will be 60 and the pen up angle will be 0. Only printable on a MENDEL!!!! The base is 14+ cm wide! Also, it'll print much better with the smaller features on a stepstruder! UPDATE: we test mounted this at my local makerbot club's meeting this Monday. The mounting holes are a little too close for the makerbot z-stage, we ended up using some tape to do the test. Will change and update in the near future, in the meantime I can confirm this works! Smoking's bad for you. And bad for your makerbot. But it sure did help me get the laser aimed here:
Calibration: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ilOzZ1QDx7A In action: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=722YzYM8xuY

Print all parts. Clean out bolt holes and slots with needle files. Use 2x M3 to attach the tower to the base.
Slide the arm down the top of the laser till it seats in the rim.
Adjust the laser to burn a spot 1-3 cm in front of the lens
Use 1x M3 to attach the arm to the tower
Use 1x M3 to clamp the arm onto the laser
slide servo into slot, use the included self-tapping screws to secure it
(optional) attach servo to EC or an arduino and set the servo position to it's default pen up position (you can use my unicorn tester as a base for this, or just send a custom M-code to the EC for it)
Use the included screw to attach a servo arm
Attach the flag to the servo arm using (I don't have screws for this! They look like self-tapping M1x3?)
Mount assembly to makerbot z-stage Use any software compatible with the unicorn to make your design. Set the feedrate to some number slow enough to ensure a good etch. Export using the pen down and up angles noted above. Turn on laser - note the pilot beam for aiming! Set the pilot beam at the reference point (either center of platform or extreme lower-left) Exclaim in a loud voice "Fire the laser!" Press build. Do not look at target with remaining good eye!

comments.text: Our local makerbot group met last night and we fired the laser!
comments.author: merlinjim

A mounting frame for the TinyG motion controller with 80mm case fan and 20-series extrusion mounts.

I made the other TinyG frame/case and found it really limiting.  
You couldn't access any screws or plugs when it was installed and it didn't have any options for actually mounting it to anything, so I thought I would come up with something more useful.  
As the majority of the TinyG's will be used with CNC routers or 3D printers, it is likely there will be some 20-series extrusion about the place, so I put some mounting holes for attaching to that.  
As the TinyG loves it some cooling, I put mounts for an 80mm case fan.  
To allow for ease of access, I made it in an X shape - it doesn't need much lateral strength, the PCB and the fan give it all the strength it will need.  
You need two parts if you want to mount it and use a fan, otherwise just print one.  
The frame works as both a top and bottom part.

A little script I made to help make the oiling process easier. If there are any errors, please let me know. This is only tested for a Cupcake CNC, so I don't know what it's going to do on a Thing-O-Matic. Theoretically it will work on any machine with at least 55mm X travel and 50mm Y travel. That last picture had to be taken with one hand holding the oil bottle, one hand holding the camera, and one foot ready to press the "Take Picture" button. UPDATE
Now includes homing support for Thing-O-Matic! Note that it is not tested. I am not responsible for broken ToMs! File is: Oil Thing-O-Matic. This basically takes the Cupcake script and inserts homing. I pulled the homing directly from the ToM ABP start.txt file. Don't worry if the Z height is wrong, it really doesn't matter.

To run the script, your machine needs to know where zero is, and then you can run it. In other words, if you move all axes to zero, the machine should put the nozzle on the platform on the center. Endstops are currently not supported. The machine will prepare for oiling and the script will produce messages to guide you through the process. It will move off to one side for you to oil, then the other side to expose the rest of the rod, then run the axis back and forth to make the oil "set in." Also, to make oiling the Y easier, it keeps the X off to one side so you have space to stick the oil bottle in. Oiling Tips:
When oiling the rod, squeeze a bit out over the length of the rod. If little drops of oil start to form hanging below the rod, take a paper towel and suck up the extra oil. The oil should cover the rod but not drip below it.

comments.text: I had to add a line "G1 X0" to keep X from ramming into the front of the machine when Y moves to the front. This is an awesome little script otherwise! Thanks!

author: messersr

description.text:
After finding the pillow blocks split on my printer and having never been satisfied with the Y Axis rigidity I made the following mods.
To prevent the new ABS pillow blocks from suffering the same fate I routed some 1.5mm aluminium clamp plates to support them. Any thicker and the screws will rub on the bottom of the heated table. The pillow blocks can be used as a jig to make these parts also.
I machined away the inner ends of the pillow blocks so that the linear bearings could be spaced further apart, this would give about a 25% increase in rigidity as the recirculating balls are not near to the end of the bearings meaning a 350mm long rail is only supported by 60mm!
The original 8mm rails were under size so some more were bought of the correct diameter and cut to the correct length. As the Y Axis toothed belt is all that holds everything together I drilled and tapped the ends M3 (The rods are only case hardened and plated however it still requires some care) and drilled some matching holes in the end pieces. Everything is now held together with M3 screws (some 3mm ID x 8mm OD card shims were needed so the magnet positions matched perfectly) making this sub assembly much more rigid by itself. These screws only need to be lightly tightened.

description.text:
Wanted to solve the fact that Gopro lens is not centered on Zenmuse H3-3D gimbal and still keeping the video connection to gopro for FPV.
Hence did the following:
1) Mounted the gopro upside down and reversed it via settings.
2) Reduced a miniUSB plug (extended version) to be able to still connect it
3) Installed wider/taller landing feet
4) Modified them to install the FPV antenna on one feet (this should reduce risk of transmission masking in some conditions
5) Made the attached feet for better landing on soft surfaces You can find also a 'snow' version (not yet tested). Now the Gopro's framing is improved a lot (wider free area) and also the Video Transmission quality reduction with the DJI coming back to me (previously the antenna was installed in the back pointing down) disappeared. If you like it please download it!
If you download it please 'LIKE' it!

title: ROBO3D Frame Mods and Z Axis Support

description.text:
The frame upper has had 40mm cut out of it so that it gives clearance for cooling fans and the like. Since chopping this bit out I have decided the whole printer looks better as well as having other benefits.
The LED lights courtesy of eBay have transformed visibility beyond what I had hoped for.
The laser cut Z axis supports just needed some M3 holes drilling and tapping and some holes drilling in the case to suit. Once everything is in place the screws in the opposing slots are tightend and then the Z axis rails are solid. When I replaced the undersize 8mm rods I made them longer to accomodate any future mods.
I placed a 6mm ball bearing in each of the Z axis flexible couplings to prevent them acting like springs upon which the whole printer suspends, not good for accuracy. Another mod was to machine a solid adapter for the coupling to fit the screwed rod as it looked like some sort of tape (PTFE) was used originally???

author: 58webbing

description.text:
The 2 Manfrotto tripods I have seem to differ in orientation and add ons so this may not be suitable for every Manfrotto.  
The 190XPROB has no additions and allows for a hanger that goes completely around it. The 055CXPRO3 has a spirit level that stops a full hanger. These 2 tripods also have the securing grubs 60 degrees off from each other.  
You'll see in the pics that the 190X (on the right in the comparison photo) has hooks with shoulders for more strength where they attach. Options are included for both models (ns in the filename means no shoulder).  
Also included are various hooks that attach. I use 30mm and 20mm double sided velcro so that's what included here for starters. I also included hooks with gaps so you can feen existing strapping onto them. If you need and specific sized hole, just add a comment I'll make one up.

I printed everything at 100% density. I can attach a battery pack weighing nearly 2kg from one hook. Your milage may vary.  
Support is probably required for the hooks unless you can bridge 8mm easily.

Update: I uploaded a version that can be click-mounted with my Raspberry Pi holder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:700900). The mounting base can be removed from the top hat rail by inserting a flat screwdriver at the bottom lug and gently bend him upwards. I'm going to upload several mounting cages for the raspberry pi etc. in the next time.

author: drj

title: moon's bolt - yet another hobbed bolt

description.text: Here is the hobbed bolt I have been using for the last 10+ months with better results than anything else (check also the complete feeder at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:73082). Time to share! Though it looks like "old school", it is extremely reliable and could prove useful to makers that do not want to buy expensive machined bolts, or that build their own filament feeders or extruders. As for me it compares favorably to MK6 and ultimaker drive bolts. Grinding and slipping is something I never experienced in the last 6 months but once with a brittle wood filament.

A few great features (imho):
  • it has a bigger diameter than M8 threads, hence it provides a better grip
  • square and large teeth replace spiky grinding small ones (hey, I do not want a file but a driving bolt)
  • central groove always leave material on the filament, which prevents grinding and crushing
  • plastic does not accumulate in the grooves as with some other hobbed bolts (including machined ones... that was a nice surprise), so no slipping occurs
  • it's easy to make (just need a drill and a dremel with steel cutting wheels plus a few clamps)
  • it's obviously ridiculously cheap
    • I described the process in my short hobbed bolt review here:
    http://betterprinter.blogspot.fr/2013/03/which-hobbed-bolt-for-filament-feeder.html The drawbacks:
  • not very good looking
  • hard to make it consistent, though the thing is impressively tolerant :)
  • compatibility with stock filament feeders / extruders
    • This thing is part of the filament feeder I made and used for the last 6+ months with excellent results (I will post it one day, now that I am at revision 5!). I printed PLA at an amazing 350+mm/s with it on my ultimaker at my fablab (with witnesses). Would it help to design yet another hobbed bolt tool? Actually, I am a bit skeptical because the cutting wheel usually wears out so quickly, that the varying diameter ruins the purpose of the tool in the first place anyway. The angle and teeth shape still would not be consistent imho.
    Check, e.g. http://www.thingiverse.com/search?q=hobbed+bolt+tool ?

These 2 off laser cut parts hold together the following excellent components to make a neat way of managing the printer head cables. Cable chain http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:643158 Hinge http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:646215 Fan ducts http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:431160. 21 02 2015 Twin fan update

These 2 off laser cut parts hold together the following excellent components to make a neat way of managing the printer head cables. Cable chain http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:643158 Hinge http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:646215 Fan ducts http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:431160. The photos should be self explanatory, M3 screws and spacers to fit. The overly stiff PVC sleeving for the stepper motors should be discarded as they are a hindrance.
On the X and Z axes the original linear bearings were discarded as they were loose and replaced with good quality std LM8UU items which protrude a bit to provide more rigidity. The X axis 8mm rods were drilled and tapped at the ends to bolt the brackets on as just relying on the toothed belt to hold things together is not good practice. The fixed end of the chain utilises the redundant M5 Z axis stop screw hole with a 12mm OD spacer. There is just enough space for everything to fit in a std case however if you want to use some efficient cooling fans I would recommend cutting the case as per http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:684756 as I think it also improves the printer appearance. I found it very easy to adjust the fan position with the hinge so I have extended the idea to the front. All pictures have been taken on a spare X axis carriage.

description.text:
I've tried many sound deflectors for my iPad mini, all had flaws, one of which is loosing much of the bass response and stereo separation the iPad's little speakers have.
I decided to design my own. It turns out the angle and thickness of the deflecting surface matters a lot. After 7 prototypes I share with you my final results:
  • Good stereo separation when used in portrait mode
  • Maximum amplification without loosing the bass
  • Small and ergonomic, you can leave it on all the time without adding much bulk
  • Stable design won't fall off the iPad
  • You can connect the lightning cable when in use
    • IMPORTANT NOTE: it's designed to fit over the iPad mini with the Smart Case. If you don't have the case I won't fit.

The Hugger is designed to fit the iPad mini with a smart case.
Print using small supports for the "hands".
It's a fast and easy print, About 50 minutes at 0.15mm

The standard Solidoodle case doesn't provide enough clearance above the extruder, which can lead to filament stripping. It's also irritating to have to use a screwdriver to remove the case, so you may end up running the printer with the case just resting on top of its fixing screws. This isn't very secure, and can be very noisy. This Thing provides a set of parts to raise the case by 25mm (enough to avoid any problems of filament fouling) and uses thumbscrews to both hold the case securely and allow quick removal.
N.B. - to make the case fit properly using this kit you will have to make some new holes in the back of your Solidoodle case. Be sure you're happy to do the metalwork before starting to make these parts. The thumbscrews are derived from Jon Bondy's highly recommended Solidoodle bed-levelling thumbscrews http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:38064 The front pillars are fitted with slots to hold a small polycarbonate window. I've provided STL files with both grouped and individual objects so you have a choice of how to print the parts.

I printed the parts in ABS with layers 3 and infill 0.2. There are big overhangs on the risers so these must be printed with support.
Before fitting the pillars you'll need to file or Dremel out some clearance to fit over the blind rivets at the corner of the Solidoodle frame. Glue the pillars in place with epoxy. The front pillars have their support slots at the front edge. I also stuck some thin rubber (old bike inner tube) on top of the pillars to help reduce rattling. Then cut a piece of polycarbonate (if you want a window) or plywood, thick card etc. to fill the open space at the front.
The risers at the front corners of the case will also benefit from having some clearance provided for the rivet heads. Then use 1/8" blind rivets (alternatively small nuts and bolts) to fix the risers to the case with the heads on the inside. You should use washers with the blind rivets or the plastic will split - the risers have holes to take standard sized washers.
The modified thumb screws have a 6mm counterbore to accomodate the head of an M3 screw, and the through hole is narrower than the original. If available, just run an M3 tap through the hole and fit a 16mm M3 screw. Alternatively, bore out the hole (before or after printing) and epoxy the M3 screw in place. Note, there's a small unsupported overhang inside the counterbore so you may need to remove a small loop of loose ABS.
If your Solidoodle is like mine, the Y-axis rods stick a few mm out of the back of the case. For the case to fit snugly you'll need to make some new clearance holes in the rear flange. Either drill and file, or use a small hole saw. The final photo shows the additional holes.
You may want to stick a strip of stout card inside the top rear flange of the case to cover the (now redundant) clearance holes for the filament feed and the cable bundle.

After printing put parts together. Just done it for sketchup make practice work.

The renderer might be down.... check out http://www.flickr.com/photos/[email protected]/3605186452/ for some pics.
When my brother came to me with a proposition to make a lens hood for his old Yashica I honestly wasn't sure how well the Makerbot would be able to pull off a task that required such fine detail: I needed something that would twist and lock onto three flanges. After just a few design iterations though, I could see that it was going to work.
For me what was so awesome was that the Makerbot allowed a very natural and intuitive design process/flow. I quickly mocked up a rough design and printed it out. This allowed me to see where problems were going to come up. I thickened it in areas and adjusted some dimensions and printed another. I went through another two iterations to finally come to the perfect design. This all happened within five hours of my brother even suggesting the idea while still having time to watch a full movie and eat dinner.
Definitely one of the most satisfying designs/things I've made especially considering this is something that is very hard to buy these days.
Thank you Makerbot!

description.text:
I got the inspiration for this from Dmatsumoto's thingiverse.com/thing:1637 calibration piece. I was having all kinds of trouble with filled-in pieces, but my Cupcake would make beautiful single strand walls.
So I drew a single strand walled box to fit a set of business cards and I added a bottom. My version has square corners because I ran into trouble in Blender when working with the rounded corners, I think it was the way I added the bottom. (I could not open the exported stl file in ReplicatorG-23 -- just a slew of error messages.)
Another challenge was that Skeinforge (35) did not like the cutout part at the top edge that you can see on the top photo. I had designed the box with the cut-out but it would just stop building at the bottom of the cutout making it a shorter box.
So I just made a square box the full height and then cut out the design afterwards.
The top fits very nicely and the "seam" that runs along the one side provides enough friction so that it does not slip off.
At 95mm it is the tallest piece Iâ€™ve made so far!
I'm also including the stl file with the cut-out design that I was not able to build, (BuinessCardBox-3.stl), maybe some of you will have better luck (or skill) than me.
Build the two pieces and then cut-out the design to provide easier access to the business cards inside the box.

author: ilan132

description.text: This bracket clips on to the back of a raspberry pi case and can be attached to the leg of the LACK table from IKEA using only a nylon zip-tie. I have started using these inexpensive tables to house and organize my gadgets and so I put my Prusa CZAR on one and realized I wanted to mount the OctoPi print server with the camera facing the print bed.   This worked out so well I will be making more! next LED light mounts and perhaps even a Prusa LACK.
15%fill 2 perimiters 1.7mm prusa czar .  No supports needed.

author: Tosamdy

description.text: I made this charm as a Valentine's day gift for my wife and daughters using Tinkercad. I made a heart shape, then copied and resized the shape to create the staggered shape. The 5mm hole is intended to fit a standard Pandora style charm bracelet.
I didn't use supports, so the steps on the bottom side are a little less pronounced, but it still printed nicely. I used a Printrbot Simple Metal without a heated base.

remixed_from.title: Prusa I3 belts tensioner - Tensor correas Prusa I3

description.text:
A quick and excellent way to improve the quality of your prints!  
This is a remix of an excellent belt tensioner, but the width of it would sometimes jam my printer and cause missed steps, and thus ruined prints.  
I trimmed 2mm from the width and 1mm from the height.

Have you ever thought that you can print on fabric? Yes? So did I. No more disconnected parts and ironing.
The main problem is "how to fasten it on the table?" Glue or pins doesn't give any satisfying results. So I thought there's need a frame. Unfortunately, plastic can't hold enought tought on it for washing.
http://youtu.be/fHNWVqJBe7k

First you need to print parts and stick the Base to the print table in the center. I use acetone-ABS glue for that.
Next fix some cotton fabric or clothe with the Ring. It must be good stretched to have a flat surface.
Third - scale your thing in one layer and print it. Important presets:
Material - PLA or fluorescent PLA (gives the best smoothness)
Layer thickness - 0.2mm (good enough for a colour and flexibility)
Temperature - 250-260C (better adhesion)
Offset - 9mm (due to holder's height)
Lift printing head Z while retract - 3mm

title: Quanum DIY FPV Goggles Vrx RC832 Cover

description.text: This is how the Quanum should be. Remove the RC832 case and wire it to the monitor. Then, add this cover and you are all done.

comments.text: Has anyone tried this on the newer V2 or V2 Pros? Screen sizes are similar but not identical.
comments.author: Outatrim

comments.text: Do you have any diagrams on how to wire the video to the input on the RC832?
comments.author: sethmo

comments.text: Does this go over the back of the screen or did you take the backing off and replace it with this? Is the transmitter still intact inside this or do you take the guts out and stick em in here?
comments.author: beno0055

comments.text: Yes it goes over the back of the screen. You don't have to take the back of the monitor off unless you want to shorten the cables as I did with mine. The video receiver was taken out of the case and placed inside, making the whole thing lighter. The wires from the monitor were soldered to the receiver.
comments.author: beno0055

comments.text: Looks like a great approach.
comments.author: robs113

comments.text: Yes, I used goop to attach the cover to the back of the quanum.
comments.author: robs113
